Award.AwardTitle: MRI Development: Upgrading NIRSPEC for a Renaissance in IR Spectroscopy at the W. M. Keck Observatory
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Near-Infrared Spectrometer (NIRSPEC), which is designed to examine infrared light emitted by stars and galaxies, has been used for hundreds of scientific studies since it was commissioned for use at the Keck II telescope atop Maunakea, Hawaii in 1999. A team of scientists and engineers from the California Association for Research in Astronomy and the University of California, Los Angeles propose to upgrade this aging instrument. The upgrade will improve NIRSPEC's sensitivity by installing modern detectors and improve its stability through a combination of upgrades to electronics, software, and the system that allows NIRSPEC to lock onto and track stars. This will give the U.S. astronomical community an unique tool to push the frontiers of knowledge in numerous areas, including understanding the clouds of gas that form new stars, the oldest and most distant parts of the universe, and asteroids in our solar system. The student participants in this project will gain skill in building complex optical instruments that will be equally well applied to future projects in astronomy and the commercial sector.

The Near-Infrared Spectrometer (NIRSPEC), a 1-5 micron moderate resolution instrument that has been operational on the 10 m Keck II telescope since 1999, has provided data for over 350 papers and 35 Ph.D. theses on a wide range of topics. The proposed work will extend the life of this instrument as well as improve its sensitivity, stability, and spectral resolution by upgrading the main spectrograph detector, adding a new slit-viewing camera, upgrading the control electronics and software, and modifying the grating mechanism. The upgraded NIRSPEC will enable a wide variety of scientific studies identified as high priority in the most recent Decadal Survey, ranging from protostellar disks and exoplanet atmospheres to solar system objects and the high-redshift universe. It will be a unique capability for the U.S. astronomical community at one of the highest impact astronomical facilities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NIRSPEC upgrade project completed the proposal goals on 9 March 2020 during the final engineering night to complete commissioning for the Infrared slit guider (SCAM). This upgrade project overhauled one of W. M. Keck Observatory's work-horse facility class instruments by modernizing the existing infrared detectors (both spectroscopic and slit viewing arrays) with new H2RG detectors that greatly improved the sensitivity of the spectrograph, provided ability to achieve higher detector-sampling-limited spectral resolution, and extended its acquisition camera capabilities to thermal wavelengths at L and M band.  Additionally, we sought to modernize the control electronics and software for the instrument, improving its operational efficiency, and critically, extending the instrument's lifetime.  Lastly, we took an opportunity to improve mechanism stability that would lead to more accurate wavelength calibration that is essential for radial velocity measurements. To do this, we updated the motor backlash and replaced components in drive systems that had been in use with NIRSPEC since it was first commissioned with the instrument. We are proud that while during the integration and commissioning, the development team was able to accommodate a NASA key project of observing a near earth flyby of comet Wirtanen.

The NIRSPEC science detector commonly called "SPEC" was upgraded from the original Aladdin III InSb 1024x1024 array to a Teledyne H2RG HgCdTe 2048x2048 array. This detector upgrade increased the wavelength coverage by a factor of two as well as improved the spectral sensitivity. The read-noise for this new system is a factor of 4 improvement over the original system commissioned 20 years ago. The SPEC upgrade required removing the detector mount and all associated cabling. In addition to the detector, the team replaced obsolete and antiquated transputer technology that was formerly used to readout the detector. A new sidecar ASICs with a Gigabit Ethernet connection to a Linux based operating system was developed and implemented as a controller replacement. The Linux based system represents an evolution in the H2RG controllers that have been deployed at the W. M. Keck Observatory with previous delivered instruments and upgrades having used a USB to Windows operating system to control H2RG detectors. 

An improvement to the user interface is a python-based image display and slit acquisition tool called Ginga. Ginga was adopted from community source code and modifications were made to support NIRSPEC image display and control. Mechanical modifications to the grating positioning and cross-disperser mechanisms have been tested and have improved the mechanical stability by a factor of 5. This mechanical work also exposed and identified the need to service and replace custom parts used to drive the rotator and echelle grating as the parts have worn over the last 20 years. Although outside the original scope of work, the observatory completed replacement activities during downtime of the instrument using observatory resources, and this activity addressed a chronic problem. 

This project also formed part of a Ph.D. Thesis for the primary graduate student working on the project at UCLA. The graduate student took a leading role in the design, assembly, integration at the summit, testing, and eventual commissioning of the spectrograph upgrade. One additional graduate student has participated in the integration activities in the later stages of the project.
